skills.name: Compare two or more bar charts

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have subtracted the numbers, rather than adding them.
explanations.B: 15 children cycle and 20 students take taxis. Adding the two numbers gives 35.
explanations.C: Almost. This is the numbers of children who take taxis, but we also need those who cycle.
explanations.D: Almost. This is the numbers of children who cycle, but we also need those who take taxis

explanations.A: This is the number of children that cycle, but we also need the people who walk.
explanations.B: Not quite. Check that you have found the number of children who cycle, those that walk, and then added these together
explanations.C: This is the number of children that walk, but we also need the people who cycle.
explanations.D: 15 children cycle and 45 walk, so in total there are 60 children.

explanations.A: I think you might have confused "most" and "least". We need the biggest bar for the most popular
explanations.B: Not quite. The bar for bananas is also smaller than the orange bar
explanations.C: Kiwi is the most popular as this bar is the biggest.
explanations.D: Not quite. The orange bar is the second tallest, so it is the second most popular fruit

explanations.A: Not quite. To be the most popular pineapple would have to be the biggest bar
explanations.B: Not quite. Kiwi is also taller than orange so is liked more.
explanations.C: I think you might have confused most and least. The most popular will be the tallest bar
explanations.D: The bar for Apples is the second largest, making it the second most popular fruit.

explanations.A: Not quite. The bar is correct
explanations.B: Not quite. The bar is correct
explanations.C: Not quite. The bar is correct
explanations.D: The bar for kiwi should be halfway between 50 and 40.

explanations.A: Not quite. The bar is correct
explanations.B: 20 children like Pineapple, but the bar reads 25.
explanations.C: Not quite. The bar is correct
explanations.D: Not quite. The bar is correct

explanations.A: The bar for banana reaches 30 and the bar for orange reaches 35.
explanations.B: Not quite. Check your bar for orange
explanations.C: These are the categories that are missing, but we need the numbers. Use the heights of the bars to find these
explanations.D: Not quite. Check your scale to make sure the numbers are correct.

explanations.A: Not quite. Check your bar for orange
explanations.B: Not quite. Check your bar for apple
explanations.C: These are the categories that are missing, but we need the numbers. Use the heights of the bars to find these
explanations.D: 20 children like Apples and 35 like Oranges.

explanations.A: Not quite. There are 2 girls and 4 boys. Be careful to check the scales
explanations.B: Not quite. There are 7 girls and 13 boys. Be careful to check the scales
explanations.C: Not quite. There are 3 girls and 1 boy. Be careful to check the scales

explanations.A: Almost. Tennis was picked by 2 more boys than girls. We need it to be 2 more girls than boys
explanations.B: Not quite. There are 7 girls and 13 boys. Be careful to check the scales
explanations.C: Netball was picked by 3 girls and 1 boy, so this is the sport
explanations.D: Not quite. There are 11 girls and 11 boys. Be careful to check the scales
